citation.article-title: Celerinatantimonas diazotrophica gen. nov., sp. nov., a nitrogen-fixing bacterium representing a new family in the Gammaproteobacteria, Celerinatantimonadaceae fam. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Celerinatantimonas diazotrophica sp. nov.

Celerinatantimonas diazotrophica [di.a′zo.tro′phi.ca. Gr. adv. dis twice, doubly; N.L. n. azotum nitrogen; N.L. pref. diazo- pertaining to dinitrogen; N.L. fem. adj. trophica (from Gr. fem. adj. trophikê) nursing, tending; N.L. fem. adj. diazotrophica growing on dinitrogen].
Displays the following properties in addition to those described for the genus.
Grows at 17–49 °C, with optimal growth at 31 °C.
Growth occurs at NaCl concentrations of 2.5–8.0 %, with optimal growth at 7.0–7.5 %.
Growth occurs at pH 3.5–8.0, with optimal growth at pH 6.0.
Does not produce the extracellular enzymes amylase, gelatinase, casein protease or lipase.
Nitrate is not reduced.

Known strains are positive for the production of acid and alkaline phosphatases, esterase, esterase lipase, leucine arylamidase, α-chymotrypsin, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, α- and β-galactosidase and β-glucosidase.
The type strain produces N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase (chitinase), but the other known strains do not.
Negative for α-fucosidase, α-glucosidase, α-mannosidase and β-glucuronidase.
Strain J-G1-2 produces weakly positive reactions for lipase (C14), cystine arylamidase and trypsin with API ZYM test strips; all other strains give negative results.
Strain J-G1-5 produces a weakly positive reaction with valine arylamidase with API ZYM test strips; all other strains are positive.

Utilizes N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, l-arabinose, d-arabitol, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, gentiobiose, α-d-glucose, myo-inositol, lactose, lactulose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melibiose, methyl β-d-glucoside, l-rhamnose, sucrose, trehalose, glycerol, cis-aconitic acid, citric acid, d-galacturonic acid, d-gluconic acid, d-glucuronic acid, α-ketoglutaric acid, succinic acid, bromosuccinic acid, dextrin, glycogen, l-proline and malate.

Does not utilize N-acetyl-d-galactosamine, i-erythritol, l-fucose, xylitol, phenylethylamine, putrescine, 2-aminoethanol, 2,3-butanediol, dl-α-glycerol phosphate, α-d-glucose 1-phosphate, d-glucose 6-phosphate, d-galacturonic acid lactone, d-glucosaminic acid, γ-hydroxybutyric acid, p-hydroxyphenylacetic acid, α-ketobutyric acid, α-ketovaleric acid, malonic acid, propionic acid, quinic acid, d-saccharic acid, sebacic acid, l-alaninamide, α-cyclodextrin, d- or l-alanine, l-alanyl glycine, l-aspartic acid, glycyl l-aspartic acid, glycyl l-glutamic acid, l-histidine, hydroxy-l-proline, l-leucine, l-ornithine, l-phenylalanine, l-pyroglutamic acid, d- or l-serine, l-threonine, dl-carnitine, urocanic acid, inosine, uridine or thymidine.

Variable results are seen for utilization of adonitol, maltose, d-psicose, raffinose, d-sorbitol, turanose, pyruvic acid methyl ester, succinic acid monomethyl ester, acetic acid, formic acid, α-hydroxybutyric acid, β-hydroxybutyric acid, itaconic acid, dl-lactic acid, succinamic acid, glucuronamide, Tweens 40 and 80, l-asparagine, l-glutamic acid and γ-aminobutyric acid.
Of these carbon sources, the type strain utilizes maltose, d-psicose, succinic acid monomethyl ester, acetic acid, dl-lactic acid, glucuronamide and l-glutamic acid.
The type strain also produces α- and β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase and acid and alkaline phosphatases.
The type strain, S-G2-2T ( = ATCC BAA-1368T = DSM 18577T), was isolated from a Spartina alterniflora root sample from the North Inlet salt marsh near Georgetown, SC, USA.
Other strains of the species, isolated from similar sources, are J-G2-2 ( = DSM 18573), J-G1-1w ( = DSM 18574), J-G1-5 ( = DSM 18575) and J-G1-2 ( = ATCC BAA-1369 = DSM 18576).
